This is a  fine lecture  by  professor Marten van Dijk on Communication  Networks. This lecture was more practical  for MIT students and for people who have interest in Computer Science. Computer Science and Electrical Engineering courses cross listed and  Communication Networks is one of them.
This one was a very nice lecture from this professor.

If anyone else was confused at the butterfly network part talking about (b1, b2,....,blogN, level) like I was.   The b1, b2,....,blogN part is the row and the subscripts of b represent the place of the binary number. so "b1, b2,....,blogN" in our case is b1,b2,b2 and an example of what that could be is 010. "level" means which column the switch is in.  so if we were to look at some switch called (x1, x2,....,xlogN, level) an example of what that switch could be in our case is (010, 0) corresponding to the switch at 3rd row down and the 1st column on the left or it could be (001, 0) which is the second row down and the first column on the left.    Abstraction is useful but when it's notation is still new to someone like it is for me you can get bogged down by silly things
What is logN equal to?

also log is log base 2 in this case
Thank you!
LogN actually gives the power of the base. For example Log(4) with the base 2 will be 2 because 2 to the power 2 gives 4...LogN will give different answers for different base.
See readings for this section: http://ocw.mit.edu/6-042JF10
Bits are zero indexed. For example, if we have a bit sequence 101, then 0th bit is 1, 1st bit is 0, 2nd bit is 1.

+1098tony Note that here N is the number of "inputs", i.e. only half of the number of "terminals" on the bottom of the tree. If you calculate the number of routers based on that notion, after some algebra tricks, you will see that the number of required routers is indeed 2N -1 ===== oops... I mean switches, not routers...

From my point of view ... this type of content is extremely hard, and with the clearness he explained, I have no complaint about ... except for the Recitation clips (we don't have it). :)

I have the feeling that's a very Dutch way of teaching (though maybe that's just my experience) - Dump information, let the information settle during recitations.  I don't hate it myself, so I don't really mind.
